[May 5, 1925.]CONFIDENTIAL. ^233^6' Section 1.[c 5855/21/18]No. 1.Mr. Austen Chamberlain to the Marquess of Crewe (Paris).(No. 1561.)My Lord, Foreign Office, May 5, 1925.YOUR despatch No. 880 of the 13th April has received the careful consideration of His Majesty's Government, and I am now in a position to furnish your Lordship with instructions concerning the communication to be made to the German Govern-ment by the Allied Governments on the cognate subjects of the execution of the military clauses of the Treaty of Versailles and the evacuation by the Allied Powers of the Cologne zone.2. As a preliminary it may be useful, for the purpose of record, to sketch briefly the course of the events which have led up to the present position. A general inspection of German armaments was, in the opinion of the Allied Powers, necessitated by the fact that military control had been in suspense during the period of German passive resistance to the Franco-Belgian pledges policy, and it was essential to establish whether or not the state of German armaments had changed during that period in order to appreciate how far the military clauses of the Treaty of Versailles had been fulfilled. This general inspection was proposed by the Allies on the 5th March, 1924, but it was only on the 30th June that it was accepted by Germany,, after considerable hesitation and some correspondence. It began on the 8th September, 1924, and lasted until the 25th January, 1925. Thus, when the time came for the Allies to take a decision regarding the evacuation of the Cologne zone for which the Treaty of Versailles indicated the date of the 10th January, 1925, provided that the conditions of the treaty had been faithfully carried out by Germany the inspection was still incomplete. Nevertheless, it had already revealed sufficient to compel the Allies to inform Germany, on the 5th January, that they had proof that Germany had not fulfilled, and could not fulfil by the 10th January, the condition precedent to the evacuation of the Cologne zone. The note in which this declaration was embodied concluded with a statement that a further communication would be sent as soon as the receipt and examination of the final report of the Inter-Allied Military Commission of Control had enabled the Allies to determine what remained to be done before Germany could be considered to have faithfully fulfilled her military obligations. The German Government protested against this decision on the 6th January, characterising it as a " measure of reprisal," and imputing to the Allies a failure to observe an obligation laid upon them by article 429 of the Treaty of Versailles, by which the progressive evacuation of the Rhineland is regulated. In a provisional reply to this note on the 26th January, the Allies declared that they could not accept the German allegations and pointed out that, according to the treaty the fifteen-year occupation of the entire Rhinelamd was only to be modified if Germany faithfully fulfilled the treaty, and that it was for the German Government, by observing their obligations, to allow the Allies to attenuate the occupation in accordance with article 429, the provisions of which the Allies for their part intended scrupulously-to observe. This point of view was disputed by the German Government in a further note, dated the 27th January, which contended that the condition precedent to evacuation had been fulfilled and expressed regret that the Allied Governments were still keeping the German Government and public opinon in ignorance of the actual facts upon which the decision to delay the evacuation of Cologne was based. No answer has so far been returned by the Allies to this communication.3. The Inter-Allied Military Commission of Control completed the report of their general inspection on German armaments on the 15th February and submitted it to the Versailles Committee. The latter forwarded it to the Ambassadors' Conference on the 28th February together with their own appreciation of the military situation in Germany as revealed by the report. It was at this stage that difficulties arose owing to differences of opinion of a minor character between His Majesty's Government and the French Government. His Majesty's Government desired that the Versailles Committee should be asked to formulate in precise terms the defaults-[13067] " B of real and practical importance which Germany should be required to make good before the evacuation of Cologne could take place and the Inter-Allied Military Commission of Control be withdrawn from Germany. The French, on the other hand, were anxious to differentiate between the respective conditions to be laid down for these two purposes, and appeared to consider that, in drawing up the demands on the fulfilment of which the evacuation of Cologne was to depend, account should be taken, not only of direct treaty infractions, but any symptoms of duplicity and bad faith revealed by the Control Commission^ report. It was not, therefore, until the 28th March that these divergencies of opinion were overcome and the matter referred back to the Versailles Committee for a precise definition of what remained to be done before the Control Commission could be withdrawn and Cologne evacuated. On the 10th April the Versailles Committee produced their report, which was enclosed in your despatch No. 880:4. This report is a satisfactory document, with which the military advisers of His Majesty's Government are in general agreement. The fortunate approximation of French and British views which it achieves alters the situation, in that it allows a modification to be made in the subsequent procedure which I had originally contemplated and for which I had until now consistently pressed. From previous despatches you are already aware that in the various discussions which I have had since the beginning of February with the French and Belgian Ambassadors in London and with M. Herriot on my way to and from Geneva, it has been generally agreed that, when the report of the Versailles Committee was available, the Allies should endeavour to come as nearly as possible to an agreement through the medium of their Ambassadors. The Allied Ministers would then meet to settle any outstanding point, and when complete agreement had been obtained a communication would be made to Germany. This, in itself, represented a departure from my original desire, which was that the Allied demands should be handed to German delegates across the table, and you will remember that I deferred to the wishes of the French Government on this matter on the understanding that the note should contain a statement that the Allies were ready to discuss with German delegates the methods of executing the demands.5. I am now prepared to meet the French Government still further by no longer insisting even upon this condition. For, if, as seems to be the case, complete agreement exists between the Allied Governments, and if their demands represent an absolute minimum, upon the satisfactory execution of which they must insist, then the position is clearly altered. In that case it is obviously no longer necessary to hold a meeting of Allied Ministers before the demands are addressed to Germany, nor, if the demands are the irreducible minimum upon the fulfilment of which we are all agreed, is there any point in having a ministerial conference with German delegates: Consequently the procedure which now commends itself to me is the following : (1) The communication to be made to the German Government should be drawn up by the Ambassadors' Conference for approval by the Allied Govern-ments; (2) when approved, it should, on the analogy of the previous notes regarding Cologne, be signed and presented by the Allied representatives at Berlin on behalf of their Governments and not in the name of the Ambassadors' Conference; and (3) any discussion of detail which may afterwards be necessary, in accordance with "the precise provisions of the Allied note itself, should be left to the Inter-Allied Military Commission of Control at Berlin.6. This procedure I am accordingly prepared to adopt on condition that the communication to the German Government is a document which embodies only those demands on the satisfactory execution of which the Allies are prepared to insist, that it leaves no point of principle undecided, and that it is of such a nature that when published, it will provide the material for a balanced and accurate view qi the state of German disarmament. I have no doubt whatever that the French Government will be prepared to meet me on this matter, just as I am prepared, as shown above, to meet what I conceive to be their view as regards procedure.7. In order to facilitate and expedite the preparation of such a communication . as.I have outlined, the War Office have, at my suggestion, drawn up the enclosed memorandum to serve as a draft for discussion. In the opinion of His Majestys Government this memorandum which reproduces to a large extent the Versailles Committee's report of the 10th April is in every way suitable for textual communication to the German Government, and they earnestly hope that their allies may see t,nI way to adopt it so far as possible as it stands. My conception is that it should i form the enclosure to a joint Allied note to Germany, of which I also encloi suggested draft. This draft note is a revised version of that forwarded to yo Sir Eyre Crowe's letter of the 6th March, which I had already approved. It has been recast to meet the altered circumstances of the moment.8. The War Office memorandum has been divided at my suggestion into four sections. The first is a statement showing the extent to which Germany has already complied with the disarmament clauses of the treaty. The second is a summary of those points of the military clauses upon which the Allies have not yet received satisfaction. The third section is a detailed list of the specific measures which Germany must carry out before Cologne is evacuated. It is divided into two parts : the first shows those which must be carried out in their entirety; the second those in regard to which the Allies, despite their strict legal rights, are now prepared to make certain concessions in the interest of a speedy and amicable settlement, provided always that the demands in the first part of the section are carried out by the German Government. The fourth and final section is a list of those concessions which the Allies have already made in the past.9. In the opinion of His Majesty's Government the third section of the memorandum includes every demand which should be made on Germany, and is at the same time the minimum upon the satisfactory execution of which the Allies should insist before either the Control Commission is withdrawn or the Cologne zone evacuated. All the concessions which the British Government consider should be made have been included in the latter part of the section.10. I would here draw attention to one of the specific points raised by your Lordship in your despatch under reply. It is the view here that the German army 'should be allowed to have gas-masks, the total number being fixed by the Control Commission, and you should press this view strongly when the question is raised at the Ambassadors' Conference. I am advised that such a concession is reasonable, and that it should be made.11. The draft covering note is very much the same as that already sent to you semi-officially on the 6th March. It answers in the same way the contention advanced in the German notes of the 6th and the 27th January that the non-evacuation of the Cologne zone constituted a reprisal and was an act of severity out of all proportion to the outstanding disarmament obligations. It contains the same categorical assurance that as soon as the military demands have been executed, the Allied Governments are prepared to waive any reservations which they might have been entitled to make in respect of other parts of the treaty, and to give orders for the evacuation of the Cologne zone.12. The points on which it differs from the version already sent to you are : (a.) It describes briefly the memorandum to be enclosed in it.(b.) It gives an undertaking regarding the withdrawal of the military commission of Control, (c.) It omits any reference to a meeting with the German representatives, orto a discussion of the methods of executing the Allied requirements. (d.) With it is enclosed the report of the 15th February of the military commission of Control.13. I request that you will now urge the Ambassadors' Conference at your early convenience to proceed without delay to the preparation of the communication to Germany, and that you will put forward the enclosed drafts as a basis. I understand from the War Office that it may be possible to avoid a further formal reference to the Versailles Committee, and I should be glad if m the interests of a speedy settlement this were found in fact to be the case.14. It will, however, be necessary to refer back to the Versailles Committee on a subsidiary but important matter. You will observe that the suggestion is made in the report of the Versailles Committee and adopted in the enclosed War Office memorandum that certain points of detail be left for decision to the Inter-Allied Military Commission of Control at Berlin. It is essential in the interests of Allied solidarity that on these points no room shall be. left for future differences of opinion between the Allied Governments which could only have a detrimental effect on the prospect of an ultimate settlement. While, therefore, discretion may be left to the Commission of Control in pure matters of detail, with which, in fact, they are alone competent to deal, it is essential that the Allies should now agree on all points of principle involved, and that instructions should be given to the Control Commission laying down the limit of concessions to which they may go. These instructions should be despatched to the Control Commission simultaneously with the communication to the German Government of the Allied demands, and I request [13067] b 2 therefore that you will propose to the Ambassadors' Conference that the matter should be referred at once to the Versailles Committee with a request to take steps to prepare the necessary action. v15. I will now revert to your despatch No. 880, in which your Lordship asked nine questions which may be summarised as follows : (1.) Do His Majesty's Government approve the list of twelve infractions drawn up by the Versailles Committee and the list of measures which Germany shall be required to fulfil in order to make good these infractions ?(2.) which of the concessions indicated by the Versailles Committee as desirable or possible do His Majesty's Government wish to adopt ?(3.) Shall the German army be allowed to have gas-masks ?(4.) Should the note communicating the requirements of the Allied Governments state the concessions which the Allied Governments are prepared to make?(5.) Is the Ambassadors' Conference to be entrusted with the task of drawing up the note to the German Government, and, if so, should the draft sent to you semi-officially on the 6th March be put forward for this purpose?(6.) Do His Majesty's Government desire that the note when drafted and approved shall be presented to the German Government by the Allied representatives in Berlin jointly ?(7.) Are His Majesty's Government prepared to leave it to the Commission of Control to decide the points of detail left unsettled by the Versailles Committee, including the extent of the concessions to be made eventually in the matter of the police ?(8.) Do His Majesty's Government still desire that there shall be a special meeting between representatives of the Allied and German Governments to discuss the requirements of the Allied Governments as set forth in their note ?(9.) What are the views of His Majesty's Government as regards the publication of the report of the Commission of Control on the general inspection ?16. The first, second, third and fourth of these questions are covered by the War Office memorandum now enclosed, while the third is specially dealt with in para-graph 10 of this despatch. The answers to the fifth and sixth are in the affirmative, and the answer to the seventh is also in the affirmative, with the proviso explained in paragraph 14 of this despatch that only points of detail, and no points of principle, are to be left to the decision of the Commission of Control. As regards question No. 8, I have explained my views in paragraph 5 above. I have already communicated these views to the German Ambassador here in my conversation with him on the 30th April, recorded in my despatch No. 797 to His Majesty's Ambassador at Berlin, a copy of which has been sent to you. In order to guard against misunder standing, a similar explanation will be sent to Lord D'Abernon for eventual communication by him to the German Government at the same time as, but independent of, the Allied note now under discussion.17. There remains only the question of publication. The note about to be sent to Germany and the memorandum which it contains will of course be published as in the case of the previous correspondence. As to the report of the Inter Allied Military Commission of Control at Berlin, you will remember thatT discussed the question of publication with M. Herriot in my conversation with him on the 16th March in Paris. I then indicated the reasons why I had been opposed to publication, but I said that in view of the fact that publication was demanded both by the German Government and by the Opposition parties in this country, I was prepared to agree to publication should M. Herriot desire it. M. Herriot stated that he himself was in favour of publication, though the French Government were divided on the subject. No decision was therefore come to at that moment upon a full reflection of everything involved. I am now of opinion that the report itself should be published, but without its annexes and without any reference to them. You will see that the enclosed draft note to Germany is intended to cover the trans-mission of the report of the Inter-Allied Commission of Control to the German Government. All that will be necessary, therefore, will be to publish the final note to the German Government with all its enclosures. To the publication of more than this I am not prepared to agree, since the publication of the annexes would serve no useful purpose, would cloud the immediate issue with a mass of technical detail and would tend to compromise certain sources of information. I understand unofficially that the French Government may request that the covering report ot the Versailles Committee, dated the 28th February, shall also be published. To this I am opposed. The report is tendencious, and is not wholly endorsed by the British General Staff. It thus depicts the situation in terms to which His Majesty's Government cannot whole-heartedly subscribe. Moreover and this is the argument which should be used if, ih fact, the French Government raise the question I see no reason, why the Allied Governments should publish any expression of opinion oiven by their advisers in order to guide them in arriving at a decision on the facts before them. It is sufficient to make public merely the report of those facts (i.e., the report of the Control Commission) and the action taken by the Allied Governments as a result of that report. If, however, as I trust, the French Government do not raise this point, your Lordship naturally will not refer to it.I am, &c.AUSTEN CHAMBERLAIN.Enclosure 1 in No. 1. Autorisation de laisser 79 canons de 37 a Wilhelmshaven ; 1 batterie de 1 canons de 88 a Brunsbiittel.Enclosure 2 in No. 1.Draft Note to the German Government..(Amended version of draft enclosed in Sir Eyre Crowe's letter of March 6 toLord Crewe.)IN their note of the 5th January the Allied Governments informed the German Government that they would be unable to proceed with the partial evacuation of the occupied territory at the date contemplated in article 429 of the Treaty of Versailles This decision was necessitated by the fact that Germany, by her failure to fulfil the terms of the treaty in respect of her disarmament obligations, had not executed the conditions upon which such evacuation depended. The Allied Governments at the same time declared their intention of awaiting the final report of the Inter-Allied Commission of Control before furnishing the German Government with a^ specific statement of those obligations which must be satisfactorily fulfilled by Germany "^ore the evacuation of the Cologne zone could be proceeded with.A copy is now enclosed of the report of the Commission of Control for the information of the German Government to meet the desire which they have expressed, provides convincing proof that the German Government have in numerous nstances failed to meet the obligations which, under the Treaty of Versailles, they ledged themselves to execute. The Allied Governments have carefully sifted the eport and have been at pains to differentiate between those infractions which constitute serious breaches of the treaty and which must be completely remedied, and I those which may be1 held to be of less importance and in regard to "which they are ! prepared to make concessions. They are now in a position to inform the German Government of their specific requirements and it should be clearly realised that the breaches of the treaty thus singled out for remedy are the most serious, but not the only, evidence of the non-fulfilment by Germany of this essential portion of the Treaty of Versailles.The whole position with regard to the accomplishment of Germany's disarma-ment obligations is set out in detail in the attached memorandum. This is divided into four sections. The first shows the extent to which Germany has already executed the military clauses of the Treaty of Versailles. The second is a summary of those parts of the military clauses upon which the Allies have not yet received satisfaction. The third is a detailed list of the specific measures which the German Government is now called upon to carry out and upon the complete execution of which the Allies must insist before Germany's disarmament obligations can be regarded as satisfactorily fulfilled. This section is divided into two parts. The first is a list of demands which must be carried out in their entirety. The second is a list of infractions on which the Allies have the right to demand complete satisfaction, but on which they are willing to make certain concessions in the interests of a speedy and amicable settlement, provided always that the demands in the first part of this section are carried out by the German Government. Finally a fourth section is added showing for the. sake of completeness the concessions which the Allies have already made in the past.Thus the measures which must be taken before Germany's disarmament obligations can be considered as sufficiently fulfilled to secure the partial evacuation of the Rhineland contemplated by article 429 of the treaty are enumerated in detail in the third section of the memorandum. The Allied Governments are confident that, given goodwill on the part of the German Government and the German authorities, the fulfilment of these points should necessitate no protracted delay. In short, it now rests with the German Government themselves to create the conditions in which evacuation can speedily be effected.The Allied Governments cannot properly close this note without correcting certain misapprehensions which are implied in the German notes of the 6th and 27th January. In the first place, and in order to prevent all possibility of misuncler-standing and misrepresentation in the future, the Allied Governments solemnly repeat that it is their intention, as already expressed in their note of the 25th January, scrupulously to observe, for their part, the terms of article 429 of the treaty. They will be ready, waiving any reservations which they might have been entitled to make in respect of Germany's obligations under other parts of the treaty, to give orders for the evacuation of the first zone of occupation in the Rhineland the moment the military demands detailed in the third section of the attached memorandum have been complied with in a manner satisfactory to the Allied Governments. The task of the Military Control Commission will then also be considered to have been sufficiently completed, and it will be withdrawn.in the second place, the Allied Governments cannot leave unchallenged the allegation contained in the German note of the 6th January, that the non-evacuation of the Cologne zone on the 10th January, 1925, constituted a reprisal. Such, a contention, as has already been indicated in the Allied note of the 25th January, is a perversion of the treaty position. It was for the German Government, by faithfully fulfilling their obligations under the treaty, themselves to earn the benefit of the evacuation of the first zone of occupation in the Rhineland as provided for under article 429. Nor can the Allied Governments agree that their decision not to evacuate on the 10th January last was an act of severity out of all proportion to the disarmament obligations which are described by the German Government vn their note as subsidiary details, which still remain to be fulfilled. On the contrary, points under the disarmament clauses of the treaty are still outstanding which the German Government were informed as long ago as September 1922 must be executed, but which they have made little or no attempt to rectify in the interval. Ihese points the so-called " five points " far from being subsidiary details of CII^l""afj ment, constitute grave infractions of the military clauses of the treaty. The Alliea i Governments must remind the German Government that if the-.Allies,for their par^ ! have solemnly declared their intention of carrying out the obligations devolving I upon them by article 429 of the treaty, they expect the German Government to no l the same, 1 The Allied Governments are anxious, however, to avoid all controversial discussion, and have only made the above observations to rectify certain evident misapprehensions embodied in the notes from the German Government of rhe 6th and the 27th January. They therefore welcome the assurance given in the German note of the 6th January to the effect that, in regard to any fundamental differences of opinion, the German Government are ready to do their share in order to attain the necessary practical result as soon as possible. Equally strong is the desire of the Allied Governments that the outstanding points embodied in the annex to this note may be settled with all despatch, and they therefore call upon the German Government solemnly and in all earnestness to carry out these remaining matters Avith all the speed and goodwill which the gravity of the situation demands, and thus, in their own words, to conclude the first stage of the fulfilment of the treaty and bring alleviation to Germany in the shape of the liberation of an important portion of occupied German territory.o
